name: API Frameworks / OpenAPI (Swagger)
description:
Description

Swagger is an open-source framework that simplifies the development, documentation, and consumption of RESTful APIs. It was created by Tony Tam and initially released in 2011. Swagger allows developers to define APIs using the OpenAPI Specification (formerly known as Swagger Specification), which provides a machine-readable representation of the API endpoints, request/response formats, and authentication methods.

It offers tools to generate interactive API documentation, client SDKs, and server stubs. With Swagger, developers can easily test and explore APIs, facilitating collaboration between backend and frontend teams.

name: Databases / PostgreSQL
description:
Description

PostgreSQL is a powerful, free, and open source object-relational database system that uses and extends the SQL language combined with many features that store and scale the most complicated data workloads. It has more than 30 years of active development on the core platform. PostgreSQL runs on all major operating systems, has been ACID-compliant since 2001, and has powerful add-ons such as the popular PostGIS geospatial database extender.

name: Databases / MongoDB
description:
Description

MongoDB is a cross-platform open-source NoSQL database management system that was created by Dwight Merriman, Eliot Horowitz, and Kevin Ryan in 2007. MongoDB stores data in flexible, JSON-like documents, allowing for dynamic schema and easy data modelling. Key features of MongoDB include horizontal scalability through sharding, automatic data distribution, and high availability through replica sets.

Experience

  • Richard

name: Databases / Redis
description:
Description

Redis, which stands for Remote Dictionary Server, is a open source, fast, in-memory database. Its most common use is for caching data. It stores strings, lists, hashes, bitmaps, geospatial data - and other structures. It can be used in clusters to add more resilience. Regarding data types and resiliency, it is more capable than memcache.

Comments

Most common use case at Nomensa would be for Drupal/LGD sites, although we don't currently use it on any of our existing sites. At a higher level, our use of Microsoft FrontDoor provides higher level caching which aids performance tremendously, but there is scope to add Redis or Memcache to the mix, particularly to improve performance further for authenticated users.

name: Databases / Memcache
description:
Description

Memcache is an open source, fast, in-memory database, similar to Redis. It's faster than Redis but is primarily used for key:value storing of data, so the data structures are far simpler and limited. It also doesn't have Redis' ability to store data to disk for more persistence, nor does it have the clustering options Redis has.

name: javaScript / Node JS
description:
Description

Node JS is a runtime for javaScript applications. Historically you would only be able to run javaScript in a browser to perform basic data fetching and/or DOM manipulation whereas today entire services can be built in javaScript.

From CMS' through to simple microservices, you can build almost anything in javaScript anywhere meaning teams can be more adaptive and flexible, essentially making your frontend devs fullstack devs.

Steep learning curve if trying to build something reaqlly complex like a CMS. Would recommend developers looked at either Express or Koa.

Projects

  • National Highways
  • Ramblers
  • East England Ambulance Service
  • Hydrogen Mapping Tool

Comments

Easy to build and run your code in Node. As an example, a Node "spider" app which could crawl through page responses, sifting through the page content and calling all linsk within to see if any were 404'ing: https://gitlab.nomensa.com/nomensa-boilerplate/link-content-checker

Node is a place where you can run most javaScript with a few exceptions (specifically around clientside - though there are workarounds in specific circumstances in the frontend frameworks.)

Developers should make sure they check support for common JS in MDN as not all JS can be used in Node JS environments.

Experience

description:
Description

A complicated yet much easier way of being able to use Node. Node is huge and there aren't many devs around who know it thoroughly. As with a lot of programming languages, there are a ton of ways to write something but really only ~5 good ways. Express is essentially a cheatsheet to support developers.

We tend to use Koa JS instead which is a slim version of express made by the same people.

name: javaScript / Typescript
description:
Description

javaScript, whilst allowing developers to use multiple data types in their functionality, falls short when it comes to type checking. TypeScript fills this gap by enabling developers to add "data security" to their code. For example, a function might have accepted a parameter type of object which could've meant any object. But now you can create a schematic type for type for that same object and the code will fail if the keys/value don't match as specified in the type.

TypeScript acts as both a safety measure in javaScript and as documentation for code.

Projects

  • National Highways
  • Ramblers
  • East England Ambulance Service
  • Hydrogen Mapping Tool

description:

Strapi is content management system built with Node. It's a CMS which offers a flexible development experience and has enough out-of-the-box functionality to use it as a content editing platform without changing any code.

For projects requiring more advanced features which aren't standard in Strapi but are present and well supported in other CMS' (such as Drupal), we should advise clients to rethink their decision to use Strapi (unless they're adamant and have adequate budget)

name: javaScript / ES6
description:
Description

ES6 is a new way to write javaScript, covering things like `import`, the lexical "this" scope (in arrow functions) and the spread operator (...). There is also the much needed date/time support in the form of the Intl object, removing the need for developers to use libraries to format ISO time numbers. And no more huge iterables in our code with the help of de-structuring. All of these are helping to make our apps faster, more secure and less bloated, utilising core functionality wherever we can.

name: javaScript / Build Tools
description:
Description

All frameworks we use have already had their build processes set up often requiring little or no extra configuration from developers. The most popular build tools used today are Webpack, Rollup or Vite.

These are responsible for building optimised production versions of our apps, transpiling the JS to make it compatible with all modern browsers and code splitting which compiles our code into smaller packets making pages load faster and making page requests much smaller.

name: javaScript / Unit Testing
description:
Description

The tools available for performing unit tests in frontend apps are: AVA, JEST, VITEST (for use on Vite built projects only), Testing Library.

Used in conjunction with the development approach of TDD where developers should build a test before writing any code. Functional requirements in a ticket should be referenced as part of this process. Once thh test is written and failing, you write the code to make the test pass.

name: javaScript / Vue JS/Nuxt
description:
Description

Created by Evan You back in 2013 and released the following year, Vue is an approachable, performant, open-source, and versatile frontend framework for building reactive user interfaces and single-page applications.

The core library focuses on views, making it easy to integrate with other libraries and existing projects. It is versatile enough to build server-side rendered and statically generated web applications using the Nuxt framework.

Comments

Consider the impact of build processes on build minutes and whether any efficiencies can be made in this area

name: PHP / Laravel

Description

Laravel is a web application framework with expressive, elegant syntax, written in PHP. It provides a solid foundation to create web apps without sweating the small things.

name: Testing / Cypress
description:
Description

Cypress is an open-source javaScript based end-to-end and component testing framework which allows developers to test web applications or components, debug them visually and automatically rum them in continous integration builds. It was created by Brian Mann and was first released in 2014.

It provides a comprehensive set of tools and APIs for testing web applications, including built-in test runners, automatic waiting, and real-time reloading. Cypress has a unique architecture that runs directly in the browser, enabling fast and efficient testing. Cypress has gained popularity due to its ease of use, powerful features, and extensive community support, making it a popular choice for web application testing.

Projects

  • National Highways
  • Ramblers
  • East England Ambulance Service
  • Hydrogen Mapping Tool

name: Testing / Jest
description:
Description

A javaScript testing framework typically used for creating unit tests

Experience

  • Ben

name: Testing / SOAPUI
description:
Description

SoapUI is an open-source testing tool primarily used for testing SOAP and RESTful web services. It was created by Eviware Software and released in 2005.

SoapUI allows developers and testers to create, execute, and validate functional and performance tests for web services. It supports various protocols and standards, including SOAP, REST, HTTP, JMS, AMF, and JDBC. SoapUI provides a user-friendly interface with powerful features such as data-driven testing, assertions, scripting, and test reporting. It also supports security testing, load testing, and mocking of web services.

name: Testing / BDD
description:
Description

An agile software development methodology that aims to enhance collaboration and communication among developers, testers, and business stakeholders.

It was introduced by Dan North in 2003. BDD focuses on defining the behavior of a system through examples and scenarios written in a human-readable format. Key features of BDD include the use of a ubiquitous language shared by all stakeholders, the creation of executable specifications called "feature files," and the implementation of test automation to validate the desired behavior.

BDD encourages a shift from traditional test-centric approaches to a more business-centric perspective, fostering a better understanding of system requirements. BDD frameworks such as Cucumber (for various programming languages) and SpecFlow (for .NET) provide tools for implementing BDD practices. By aligning development with business goals, BDD helps teams deliver software that meets customer expectations and promotes collaboration throughout the development lifecycle.

name: Testing / Jmeter
description:
Description

JMeter is an open-source Java-based tool designed for load testing, performance testing, and functional testing of applications. It was created by Stefano Mazzocchi and was first released in 1998. JMeter allows developers to simulate real-world user traffic on a web server, database, or any other type of application, measuring its performance and response under different loads.

It supports various protocols like HTTP, FTP, JDBC, and more, making it versatile for testing different types of applications. JMeter provides a user-friendly graphical interface for creating test plans, setting up test scenarios, and analysing results.

Projects

  • Colchester Council

Comments

Azure load testing resource supports running JMeter scripts

Experience

  • Ben

name: Testing / Playwright
description:
Description

Playwright is a framework for Web Testing and Automation. It allows testing Chromium, Firefox and WebKit with a single API.
